body: Hi Alessandro, I used Radiance  to process your image.  Assuming that we start with the file that you posted, [](http://api.ning.com:80/files/9OMIaoRy6ovp2ZHJz3JNlqhvph0sgfUtyATtM9zAAmFzN9ScM55a-gQlRhhPY6pslD-IaYhXGeQBz8j0Uj2lQZwJOjID2Ad2/unnamed_IMG_interno.bmp) the steps are: 1. Reduce the exposure of the original image and save it as a different file. pfilt -e -2 unnamed_IMG_interno.HDR > unnamed_IMG_interno_filt.hdr [](http://api.ning.com:80/files/9OMIaoRy6oumEoacRS50iXun5W8UOXQsKlgYDZJoz5*vYZ08vvqEhXu3UElLFtztAi35X-efshDxxWkeg3qgfQkO4I3fD9r7/unnamed_IMG_interno_filt.bmp) 2.Use the original image and filtered image together in falsecolor. Falsecolor will do the analysis on the original image but overlay the results from the analysis on the filtered image. falsecolor -cl -i unnamed_IMG_interno.hdr -p unnamed_IMG_interno_filt.hdr > unnamed_IMG_interno_contours.hdr [](http://api.ning.com:80/files/9OMIaoRy6ou9KcZKttElHKhquddt43rLh1jQqvcbm4HEP1Ui5qWT51lkBekGkyz3U7UqRMyovruzU3uvUBkv68lfRzFxZ4BO/x.bmp) The issue is that falsecolor doesn't exist in the windows installation of Radiance as a .exe binary file. It exists as a .pl perl file. So, you'd have to have perl installed on your computer and added to your PATH variable to make this thing work smoothly. This is what I know/think anyway.
